Memorandum

Mr. Padley:

My estimate for the erection of the proposed Cross Lake Boarding school according to the latest plans is sixty two thousand dollars, $62,000.00, approximately.

The water supply and sewage disposal system are not included in this estimate as no definite information could be obtained regarding the source of water and other necessary data to prepare specifications for these works which will have to be done later as an extra.

Ottawa, 17th September, 1915.
Sir,

I beg to submit a report of my visit to Cross Lake day school on the 29th of November. This school is held in a building by Councillor Thomas Ross for which the Department pay a rent of five dollars per month.

The building is inadequate to the need; it is poorly lighted and badly ventilated, the floor is rough and difficult to clean. I wish to impress upon the Department the urgent need of a new school building.

The number of children on the register is 26. There are also ten white children attending the school. The teacher Mr Hargreaves reports that the pupils who attend regularly are making progress. The attendance is improving since the freeze up. Twelve new school desks are required for this school. Respectfully submitted,

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

Ottawa, February 1, 1916.

Sir,

In reply to your letter of the 1st of December last, I beg to say that there is no immediate prospect of a new building for the Grass Lake Day School, as, owing to the war, the appropriation for Indian schools has been materially reduced.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

J. Jones, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Norway House, Man.
Sir,

I beg to advise you that I made a visit to Cross Lake. Leaving here on Friday the 17th and returning Wednesday the 22nd. While at Cross Lake I visited the Day School, The Boarding School and the Field Matron. My visit was made in accordance with a promise made to the Chief last February to take the interpreter down to supervise the erection of the school house. I found however that the Chief had not returned from his spring hunt and that no attempt had been made to secure the logs required for the building. There were quite a number of the band doing nothing for some time before leaving for the spring hunt and there would not have been any difficulty at that time in securing the logs if they had wished to do so. As it is now the Indians will not be back until about the 27th of the month and if they are going to accomplish anything in the way of gardening their time will be fully taken up during the early part of June and there is no prospect of getting out the logs before the middle of next month. As it is now the erection of the school depends on the initiative of the Indians and if they do nothing the prospect of securing a proper building for next winter is rather slim.

As mentioned above the majority of the Indians are absent from the reserve, the season is backward and there is no work being done on the reserve at the present time. Planting will be later than usual.

I have the honor to be

Sir

Your obedient servant

The Aest. Deputy and Secretary
Dept Indian Affairs
Ottawa.

August 24th, 1933,

Dear Dr. McGill:

I beg to report as follows on the St. Joseph's
R.C. Indian Day School at Cross Lake inspected August 7th,
1933.

Since the boarding school burned the class-
room work has been carried on in the old log Church.

The Sisters state they have an enrollment of
thirty with an average of from sixteen to eighteen.

The equipment for this school is null. Lumber
should be provided for seats and tables. Blackboard space
is also needed and two or three new sections should be pro-
vided. The expense necessary to do this would be very
little and would greatly encourage those trying to carry on
this work.

I understand a grant is provided for seven
pupils all of whom are kept in residence during the school
year.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

your obedient servant,

A.G. Hamilton,
Inspector.
Manitoba Inspectorate.

Dr. Harold W. McGill,
Deputy Superintendent General,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.
Ottawa, August 30, 1933.

Sir:

I have been directed to acknowledge receipt of your report of the 24th instant on your inspection of the R. C. Indian Day School at Cross Lake.

It is noted that more blackboard space is required and also lumber to make seats and tables. If you are aware of the quantity and the dimensions of the lumber required to make up the seats and tables, I would request that you make purchase from a firm on the approved list. You should see that only the quantity absolutely necessary is supplied and that shipment is made to the school before navigation closes.

You may also purchase a small quantity of blackboard, not slate, from a school supply house in Winnipeg and have same forwarded.

Please obtain itemized accounts, in triplicate, covering the cost of the materials, and receipts for the freight charges prepaid. The accounts should be certified and forwarded for payment.

Your obedient servant,

T. R. L. MacInnes,
Acting Secretary.

A. G. Hamilton, Esq.,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Inspector's Office,
Winnipeg, Man.

Dear Sir,

Every summer we use to receive from Indian Department for our Day School, beside the Biscuits: 1 Sack of Beans; 20 lbs Cocoa; some salt; also soap - 1 Broom; some knitting yarn. Until now we have received nothing but biscuits. Hoping you will help us, obtaining these goods for our school. Certainly we need these as well as other Denominations, as we use every day to serve a full meal, at noon, to all our pupils. Kindly please take this matter into your consideration and oblige

Yours very truly,

Signed:- Rev: Henry Boissin. O.M.I.  
Principal.
Ref: 5-A

Sir,

I beg to forward herewith a copy of a letter I received today from the Rev. Henry Boissin O.M.I., Principal of the Cross Lake Roman Catholic Indian Residential School, requesting to be supplied with beans, Cocoa, Salt, Soap, Broom, and Yarn.

Will you please advise me if I may purchase these goods for this school locally, and ship them out.

I may say that I have recently purchased, and am shipping out today to the Cross Lake United Church Day School, the goods enumerated in Departmental letter No; 123-2-5 dated May 21st last, and I expect the R.C.Day School hope to be supplied with a similar quantity, as they have about the same number of pupils.

I should be glad of an early reply, so that I may get the goods sent out to Cross Lake before canoe travel stops, if the purchase is authorized.

Your obedient Servant,

F.G. Dagenais,
Indian Agent.

Department of Indian Affairs

Ottawa, November 20, 1935.

Dear Sir:

Rev. Bro. Menard visited the Department today, and he is being authorized to purchase the following articles for the Cross Lake R. C. Indian Day School:

- 1 "Big Ben" alarm clock,
- 1 school lamp,
- 6 window blinds,
- 1 drinking water tank and cups,
- 45 coat hooks,
- 3 door mats,
- 1 football.

He will forward the accounts covering the cost of the above to you, and on receipt of same, you should attach to proper voucher forms, certify and forward to the Department for payment.

The Department is placing an order for 20 pupils' desks and a teacher's desk for this school. The accounts covering the cost of these will also be forwarded to you, and on receipt of the desks, in good order, you should certify the accounts and forward to the Department for payment.

Please arrange to have the accounts for the above reach the Department before the end of March.

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

P. G. Lazenby, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Norway House, Man.
Ottawa, November 21, 1935.

Ottawa, April 1st, 1936.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 13th ultimo, forwarding a voucher for $1,056.05, in favour of Right Reverend Bishop Lajeunesse, for labour and materials in the construction of a new building at the Cross Lake R. C. Indian Day School.

In this connection I would refer you to official letter dated November 21, 1935, in which you were informed that, in conversation with Rev. Brother Menard, who visited the Department, we would consider payment of accounts to the amount of approximately $600.00. This was the full amount that was available in our Appropriation for the fiscal year ended yesterday. Cheques, in payment of the following accounts, are being forwarded to Bishop Lajeunesse:

| Payment of Wages | - | - | - | $368.00 |
|------------------|--|--|--|--------|
| Beaver Lumber Company, Limited | - | - | - | 189.10 |
| Ashdown Hardware Co., Limited | - | - | - | 103.09 |

$660.19

In the account of the Beaver Lumber Company, Limited, there was a charge for freight, to the amount of $17.35. There is no paid freight receipt accompanying the voucher and this item has been disallowed. I am returning herewith the voucher which you submitted, together with a statement of the materials used in the construction of the building. This Department will be unable to pay any further amount than that stated above, and the church authorities will have to be responsible for the balance of the expense in the erection of the building.

Enclosure.

P. G. Lazenby, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Norway House, Man.

Yours truly,

Secretary.

Winnipeg, Man., July 11th, 1939.

Dr. H.W. McGill:

Dear Sir:

I wish to submit the following report on my recent inspection of the Norway House reserve.

In closing this report I would like to refer to conditions at Cross Lake as reported by Dr. Turpel, who returned from there just after I arrived at Norway House. The Doctor reports that the Indians working on the erection of the R.C. Boarding school have some work and are getting by. On the other hand, those Indians who cannot get work are in need, especially some of the older people. The doctor arranged for temporary relief for the most distressing cases. There are almost 700 Indians in this band and, although the fur catch was better this year, it was not large so that at the end of trapping the Indians were perhaps still in debt. Relief is issued to half-breeds in this district and no doubt this adds to the treaty Indians' unrest. Mr. Lazenby will be at Cross Lake shortly paying treaty and authority should be granted for him to deal then with relief urgently needed. After then, on his return, report his findings and make some definite recommendations. Mr. Lazenby has foreseen this need and requested money for road work; however, I understand this has been refused.

A. G. Hamilton,
Inspector of Indian Agencies
Manitoba.
A. G. Hamilton:
Ottawa, Aug. 8, 1939.

Dear Sir:

I wish to acknowledge your report on the Norway House Agency, dated the 11th ultimo, your file 207-9.

You probably have been advised that a school is to be built at Cross Lake this summer and most of the work is to be done by Indian labour, therefore, these Indians should be fairly well off for work when this building is started.

M. Christianson,
General Supt. of Agencies.
A. G. Hamilton:

Dear Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter No. 207-9, of the 8th instant, quoting extracts from Departmental letter to you of the 8th instant.

With regard to the first paragraph quoted, I may say that the population of the Cross Lake Reserve, at Treaty time was 715, and is divided practically evenly between the R.C. and U.G. religions. In connection with the construction of the new school at this reserve, which school is under the auspices of the R.C. church, I was informed both by the Indians and the lay Brothers at the R.C. Mission, that only those of the band who belong to the R.C. church are given work at the school, and consequently those Indians are not in need of any measure of relief, whereas the other half of the band have no work to do, at which they can earn much of a living at the present time. However, since treaty time, I have had no requests for relief from Cross Lake, excepting for one or two of the old people. A supply of groceries has been requisitioned for, as last year, for sale at cost to Indians of this band to enable them to start out to their trapping camps, the payment for these groceries to be protected by the Indians' treaty money. This scheme has been a great help to them as it enables them to reduce their indebtedness to the trader's stores for credit. Provision is being made in the estimates for next year, for some relief road work at this reserve, as per instructions received from Ottawa.

P. G. Lazenby,
Indian Agent.

Attention: Mr Bernard F. Neary

Re: R.C. Day School - Cross Lake

On Dec 9 I visited the new R.C. Day School at Cross Lake. There were 35 pupils present and the school was full to the point of being overcrowded. The building is in good condition and the classroom neat and tidy. Sister St Luke the teacher has everything well organized. The children are all beginners and therefore in one grade. There were 3 non-treaty children there and I informed Father Trudeau that they would have to leave and attend the Public School which is only a mile distant. Sister St Luke requests that she be allowed $15.00 per month to supply a mid-day meal. They have a room in the same building where this meal could be served. I enclose requisitions for this Day School and request that the material required be sent as soon as possible addressed to the Rev Father G.E. Trudeau OMI, Cross Lake R.C. Indian Day School via Wabowden. Goods can reach Cross Lake via Wabowden as late as March 20th.

Some articles which were needed for the school such as brooms, soap, towling, pails, I purchased locally while at Cross Lake, from the Hudson's Bay Company. These articles I have checked off in red on the list which is herewith submitted.

E.B. Goodman,
Indian Agent.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dep't of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

Attention: Mr Bernard F. Neary

Re: Next Year's Building Program for Schools Particularly Inland

While in Winnipeg recently I was informed by Mr Hamilton that he has recommended the building of 3 new day schools and teacherages in this Agency for next year allocated as follows:

- R.C. Day School - Cross Lake
- U.C. Day School - God's Lake Narrows
- U.C. Day School - Garden Hill, Island Lake.

If these are approved now is the time that we should be purchasing the material and having it assembled at Ilford. The R.C. Day School at Cross Lake can be taken care of in the normal manner and we have no immediate worry about it.

#2 U.C. Day School at God's Lake Narrows - every last item for this school will have to be shipped in from outside. This should be done soon.

The U.C. Day School - Garden Hill, Island Lake. The lumber & shingles can be supplied locally but the rest will have to be imported and this also should be attended to now.

Will you please indicate what type of buildings you wish erected. There should be a 2 roomed school built at Garden Hill.

E.B. Goodman,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, November 10, 1947.

Mr. E. B. Goodman, Indian Agent,
Norway House, Manitoba.

1948-49 Building Program - Norway House Agency

Reference - your 9-B of October 16 -

Please find attached a bill of materials for the standard one-room Indian day school and combined teacherage. I promised you that I would let you have such a bill of materials this winter so that you could submit requisitions for the materials needed at the three schools which we hope to build next year.

We have been negotiating for some time with the North American Builders, Limited, in Winnipeg, with regard to the prefabrication of this combined one-room school and teacherage. They have now produced a plan which is fairly satisfactory to us. Could you please advise me as to the feasibility of ordering one or more of these schools for your agency.

If you wish to have these schools constructed in the normal manner, I presume that the following action will be taken:

(a) For the R. C. Day School at Cross Lake we will receive a requisition based on the attached bill of materials for those supplies which cannot be purchased locally.

(b) For the U. C. Day School at God's Lake Narrows, that we will either receive a recommendation that we purchase the entire bill of materials outside or that we should erect a prefabricated school.

(c) U. C. Day School - Garden Hill - Island Lake - as far (a) above.

Encl.

1948-49 Building Program - Norway House Agency.

Ref: Dep't letter 123-9-5 (W.T.)
November 10th 1947

I wish to make the following recommendations with regard to the proposed building of three new Day Schools and Teacherages in this Agency:

(a) For Cross Lake R.C. Day School, a combined school and teacherage as per the blueprint you sent me. I submit herewith a requisition for materials, based on the bill of materials for school and teacherages which goes with the blueprint. I have omitted all materials, lumber, shingles, etc., which we can produce locally. I have substituted ten-test, one inch thick in place of ½" thick gypsum board for classroom walls and ceilings. I have done this as by experience I have found gypsum board too brittle and heavy to stand the rough handling involved in northern transportation. We sustained a 40% loss on a shipment of gypsum board for the U.C. School and Teacherage at Cross Lake this summer, and I advise against a repetition of its use in future in this inaccessible region. I am unable to make a more detailed requisition for windows as at the time of compiling the requisition, the blueprint was in the possession of Sub-agent Stevenson to whom I had sent it for perusal, and it was impossible to obtain its return on short notice. I trust that the requisition as submitted is sufficiently comprehensive.

(b) For the U.C. Day School at God's Lake Narrows, I recommend that we should erect a prefabricated school and a prefabricated teacherage. The teacherage to be similar to the one erected at the C. of E. Day School at Jack River, which is simple to erect, compact and satisfactory as a dwelling.

(c) For the U.C. Day School at Garden Hill, Island Lake, the same as for the Cross Lake R.C. Day School (a) above. I am submitting only the one requisition as requirements are an exact duplicate for this school also; lumber, shingles, etc., being supplied locally. I assumed that it would be unnecessary to submit two requisitions. It is necessary to get it in this week's mail and in order to do so, I had not sufficient time at my disposal to compile two separate requisitions. However if a second is required, I can submit a second from our copy.

With regard to shipping instructions:

(a) Cross Lake R.C. Day School, as indicated at
indicated at/

head of requisition, to reach Wabowden not later than 4th March 1948. I suggest that Tom Lamb be approached regarding the transportation of this building material from Wabowden to Cross Lake. He has several tractor trains operating out of Wabowden, and our own tractor will have all it can do to take care of our logging operations before the end of the season.

(b) God's Lake Prefabricated School and Teacherage. These should be shipped to Ilford, in care of Rev: Howard Gibson, God's Lake Narrows, to arrive at Ilford not later than 12th February 1948. There are three transportation companies operating out of Ilford, i.e. - Johnson Transportation Co. with headquarters at Ilford; Northern Transportation Co. with headquarters at Favourable Lake, Ont; and B. & S. Transportation Co. headquarters unknown to the writer.

(c) Island Lake U.C. Combined School and Teacherage. To be shipped c/o Assistant Agent R.L. Stevenson to Ilford, and to arrive at Ilford not later than 12th February 1948. To be transported by one of the above mentioned transportation companies.

E. B. Goodman,
Indian Agent.

DEPARTMENTAL PURCHASING AGENT

Requisitions for Buildings Supplies for -
(1) Cross Lake R.C. Day School,
(2) Island Lake U.C. Day School.

The above day schools are to be built in the Norway House Agency next summer. As the only means of transportation for heavy supplies is by tractor train, it is necessary to purchase these building materials now.

You will note the following closing dates of tractor train departures,-

(a) For Cross Lake, to reach Wabowden not later than March, 1948.

(b) For Island Lake, to reach Ilford not later than February, 1948.

You will note that these requisitions are for the standard bill of materials of our usual one room Indian day school with attached teachersage. The only deletions are for the dimension lumber which our own Indian sawmills are providing. The sole difference between the two requisitions is that we are ordering insul-bric siding and extra nails for Island Lake because the mill there will not turn out lumber siding.

In view of the short period of time left to you to arrange for purchase orders, it is suggested that you order these materials from the same firms who supplied identical materials and quantities.
for the Oak River Indian Day School in the Griswold Agency (Your Purchase Orders 24391, etc.).

It will be necessary for the firm supplying Millwork to be supplied with a complete set of blueprints and a copy of the specifications for the school building and outside toilets. All dimensions and descriptions of the items required are shown or noted and are to be followed closely. All lumber for Millwork to be of No. 1 factory cuts, B.C. fir or equal pine.

Bernard F. Neary
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

1948-49 Building Program - Norway House Agency

Reference your letters of December 19 and December 27 - on File 9-8

We have taken the following action with regard to the proposed building of three new day schools and teacherages in your Agency:

(a) Cross Lake R.C. Indian Day School -

We have forwarded a requisition to our Departmental Purchasing Agent for the building materials listed on your requisition. We have asked that these building materials be ordered to reach Wabowden not later than 4 March, 1948. Inspector Hamilton is being forwarded a copy of this letter and is requested to approach Tom Lamb regarding the transportation of these supplies from Wabowden to Cross Lake.

(b) Island Lake U.C. Day School -

We have forwarded a bill of materials for this school to our Departmental Purchasing Agent with the request that the supplies reach Ilford not later than 12 February, 1948. We have asked that these supplies be forwarded via Johnson Transportation Company. If Inspector Hamilton wishes to advise concerning the two other transportation companies at Ilford, we will be glad to hear from him.

Your comments concerning the gypsum board have been noted and we have substituted Ten-test, as required.

........... Sth
With regard to the siding for the Island Lake School, we have substituted Insul-brick for Asbestos-siding shingles. We have found that Asbestos-siding shingles sustain a great loss in shipping even on the railways. Therefore we have replaced this item with Insul-brick and hope that it will prove satisfactory. If you wish literature on the method of applying Insul-brick, I would suggest you contact the firm supplying it when you receive the purchase order.

God's Lake Narrows U.C. Day School -

Unfortunately, North American Builders Limited have such a large quantity of orders from the Army and Department of Transport ahead of them, that they will not be able to build our prefabricated schools until the late spring. Therefore, we have no alternative other than to place the order for this school and request that it be delivered as early in the winter as the tractor train shipments are made. We regret this action, but so many other concerns are ordering prefabricated buildings, that we must wait our turn for delivery.

I would draw your attention to the policy of the Department in naming these day schools so as to provide a minimum confusion in our filing system here. At the present time there is considerable confusion concerning the naming of the schools in your agency. For example, we are now dealing with three Cross Lake Schools, namely,

Cross Lake Residential School,
Cross Lake U. C. Day School,
Cross Lake R. C. Day School.

A similar situation exists at God's Lake, at Oxford House and at Island Lake. The inevitable errors have occurred in filing accounts, letters, etc., and in the filling of requisitions and orders.

I have discussed this matter with Major Clark and we would like to hear your views concerning other names

...... for
for certain of your schools. Similar situations have arisen in other agencies when new schools were being built. For example, we have a school at Fisher River but a new one is under construction there now. Rather than have a Fisher River No. 2, we have accepted Mr. Indian Agent Lumsden's suggestion that it be named the "Hurdock Indian Day School", after the present Chief. Major Clark suggested the name Sagitouek for one of the Gross Lake schools. We will expect to hear further from you in this regard.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER.

Sagittawack Indian Day School
Garden Hill Indian Day School.

The above two Indian Day Schools are in the Norway House Agency and are both included in our 1948-49 Main Estimates. During the winter, materials for both these buildings were purchased by the Departmental Purchasing Agent and were shipped in to the sites of the schools by tractor train. It is our intention to erect these buildings with Indian labour under the supervision of a White foreman carpenter and his helper. We would like to recommend for your approval, the hiring of Mr. Earl Adams of The Pas as foreman to supervise the construction of both these schools. Mr. Adams has had considerable experience working for the Provincial Government and last year undertook the construction of an Indian Day School at Cross Lake. His work was entirely satisfactory and he is again recommended for employment this summer by Mr. Indian Superintendent Goodman.

Last year we paid Mr. Adams at the rate of $1.25 per hour and board ($40. per month). This rate is the same as that being paid to Hudson Bay carpenters in this area, and was approved by Mr. Jackson on August 12, 1947 for the Cross Lake School. The only other expenditure with regard to the hiring of this carpenter and his helper is that we pay his air transportation from Wabowden (approximately $40.).

I would like to again recommend the hiring of Mr. Adams for the duties of foreman at the construction of these two Indian Day Schools.

APPROVED

Director

Extract from Regional Supervisor Davis' report dated January 4th on the Sagitowack Indian Day School.

This school is taught by Miss McDonald and is a new building, built, I believe, in 1947. It is a very good classroom and very airy. There are 38 children on the register, 34 of which were in the classroom at the time of my visit.

Miss McDonald is a very good teacher and discipline was excellent. A new R.C. school is being built this year and is only a few hundred yards away. When this school is opened it will reduce Miss McDonald's classroom in half. It appears to me that when putting up this school, the Department was poorly advised, as the one school would have handled all the pupils - as it is doing now. If the new school had been on some other reserve it would have been more use and less cost, in the long run to the Department.

This is the above mentioned school, which has not been completed as yet. It is a combination two-room building. The workmanship is fair, however, the cement work is not of the best. This is caused by the material it was necessary to use. The rocks that were put into the cement are oversized, and did not make as smooth a job as would have been otherwise. However, the foundation is quite strong, and after having a coat of cement it will be quite alright. This school should be completed by the time of writing - with the exception of trimming on the cement outside.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dep't Mines & Resources, Ottawa

Would you please check and ascertain when delivery of this equipment may be expected as the school is nearing completion.

Dear Sir,

In reporting on the R.C. School at Sagittawuk, I wish to advise that some filling around the foundation is necessary. The yard should be cleared of brush, some scaffolding is to be taken down. Superintendent of Education:

Proposed Day School at Fort Alexander for Roman Catholic Indians:

Further study of possible sites was made today in company with Mr. Supt. Olson. Various matters related to siting and attendance were discussed with the Reverend Principal and Sister Superior of Fort Alexander Residential School, Miss Turner (the Anglican Day School teacher) and Rev. Canon Walters, the resident Anglican priest and missionary.

It is generally agreed to regard the river as a barrier too formidable to be negotiated daily by children going between home and school.

It will be easier to get forty day pupils within a convenient radius to attend a school on the left bank, the side on which are located the majority of homes, the Church, the schools, the road and the electricity and telephone lines.

The Roman Catholic population clusters about a mile down-river from their school, stretching up-river past the school to an area about two and a half miles up-river from the residential school. In this area the denominations are mingled with Protestants in the majority near their own school.
Employment opportunities at Pine Falls and up-river are likely to hold the Indians from moving farther down-river. The residential school seems the farthest down-river point at which a day school might be sited. The day school might, indeed, be sited a half-mile or so up-river from the residential school (near the Oblate Fathers' Park) but the shortened walk for a minority of those attending would entail the loss of several advantages offered by close proximity to the residential school—good water, easy power hook-up, play space and apparatus, ease of staffing and supervision, better grouping of pupils by grades and generally unification rather than disintegration of the educational, cultural and religious effort. An integrated recreational programme would also be easier to effect.

Rev. Fr. Brachet is agreeable to placing the day school building on the south side of the residential school on ground presently occupied by an old ice-house, and balancing the preventorium. In this position a teacherage would not be needed. Instead, it is desired that the classroom be elongated to at least fifty feet (Plan 888 calls for a building fifty-nine feet long). This room would be a beginners' classroom and could serve as a picture-theatre, etc. The Principal agrees to merge day-pupils and boarders in this and other classrooms.

On the right (north) bank two classrooms for day pupils will be needed. Research on statistics and siting of these schools (one for each denomination) is proceeding with a view to requesting funds for the simultaneous construction of two schools in the fiscal year 1950-51.

Fort Alexander Indian Day School

Included in our estimates is a sum of $14,000.00 for the erection of the Fort Alexander #2 Indian Day School. Dear Sir:

Re: Fort Alexander Indian Day School

Mr. Davis is presently away on an inspection trip in the north and this afternoon I had a visit from Father Brachet of the Fort Alexander Indian Residential School. The Father made a request that a full basement be installed in the new school, which is being erected at the Fort Alexander Reserve, the tenders for which close on the 19th of August.

The Father further stated that Mr. Davis had practically promised a basement for this school. In view of this statement I managed to contact Mr. Davis by telephone at The Pas and he requested me to advise you of the visit that the Father had made to this office. Mr. Davis' opinion on the matter is that certainly a basement would probably be a good feature but he stated that if a basement was included in the Fort Alexander School then, no doubt, we would be having a goodly number of requests from other schools for the same feature.

I am advising Father Brachet tomorrow to the effect that I have written to you regarding his request and also advising him to the effect that I contacted Mr. Davis and it was at Mr. Davis' request that I forwarded to you the foregoing information.

THE GOVERNOR GENERAL IN COUNCIL,

The undersigned has the honour to report:

THAT funds are available for this purpose in Vote 230, 1949-50, Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources.

The undersigned, therefore, recommends the acceptance of the tender of North American Buildings, Limited, of Winnipeg, Manitoba, for the erection of this one-room school with attached teacher's residence, for the amount of Eleven Thousand Four Hundred and Two Dollars and Eighty-seven Cents ($11,402.67).

Respectfully submitted,

Sir:

Re: God's Lake R.C.D. Day School Teacher's salary for 1946.

In November of last year, I received from the Treasury Department a cheque amounting to Three Hundred Ten Dollars and Eighty-three ($310.83) in payment of teaching days just in at God's Lake R.C. Indian Day School. In vain do I succeed to figure out how you arrived at that amount, barring your calculations on the school reports which have been forwarded to you through your Department's Agency at Norway House.

These reports compiled directly in accordance with the Register kept at the School give in the Column "Remarks," the following data:

Holidays:
- Treaty: 8 days
- Windbound: 1 day
- Canada Day: 1 day
- School open: 50 days

Total number of school days: 55 days

If you consider that in the months of June, July and August, 1946, there were only thirteen (13) "five day" weeks, making sixty-five school days, holidays permitted as indicated in the Register included,
My total salary should be sixty-five cents (55¢) of three times "One Hundred Twenty" monthly salary ($3 x $120.00) plus cost of living bonus, giving, if my calculations are correct, Three Hundred Four Dollars and sixty-one Cents ($304.61) plus Cost of living bonus, instead of Three Hundred Ten and Eighty-three Cents ($310.83) Cost of living bonus included.

You may have wondered with reason how I arrived at the total number of school days marked on the report. I am sorry not to have stated that school was kept opened on Saturdays, with an attendance sometimes even better than the normal. Your calculations probably considered only normal five day weeks as required, and not "six day" weeks which I just did.

I am sure you will kindly excuse my delay in taking the matter up with you directly, and make good the difference due me.

Thanking you in advance for your trouble,

Leon Levasseur

Yours truly,

At the God's Lake Reserve, there is no school building, properly speaking, at either the U.C. or R.C. missions. These are both "Seasonal" schools being operated for three months in the summer time. Sir,

I beg to refer you to Mr. R.A. Hoey's letter No. 123-13-5, dated 5th February 1938, in which authority was granted for the construction of 12 double school desks at a cost of $7.50 each, including labour and material, for the God's Lake R.C. Indian Day School. Brother Cordeau was authorized to make these desks.

On receiving the necessary authority, Brother Cordeau prepared the materials for all the desks, and had assembled two of them. He was then called away from God's Lake, to work on the new R.C. Residential School at Cross Lake, and in consequence the desks were not completed until this summer, when the teacher, Mr. Honsinger did the work.

The Priest in charge of the R.C. Mission at God's Lake has now advised me that the desks have been completed, and asks if the payment can still be made. The matter was discussed when I was at God's Lake last summer for treaty payment, as at that time the desks were not finished.

The original authority of course automatically expired at the close of the fiscal year 1938-39.

Will you please advise me if a new authority might be granted for payment for these desks, so that I may advise the Priest in charge, (Rev.: L. Poirier O.M.I.).

Your obedient Servant

Re: God's Lake R.C. School.

If it is the intention of the Department to build a new R.C. Day School at God's Lake this summer—which I feel we should, as one is badly needed—all the common sheeting; two by four's; two by six's; and two by eight's, could be shipped from our sawmill at Island Lake.

After an exchange of communications with Mr. Indian Agent Stevenson and Mr. Commissioner Graham, concerning educational requirements for the children at the south end of the Peguis Reserve, it has been decided to erect a classroom and a teacher's residence, probably on Section 7, Township 26, Range 1, W. P - the school to be known as the Peguis West Indian Day School. Classroom accommodation for 35 children is required. A note has been made for the 1931-32 Estimates.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6249, file 550-5, part 1)
In the latter part of your No. 136-5-5, I note that you state you hope to provide funds next year for another residence and school to be known as the Peguis West Indian Day School. In connection with the site for this school, when Inspector Christianson last visited the school he held a meeting of the Indians on the south end of the reserve. The Chief and Councillors were there, as well as all Indians concerned in the erection of a new day school. The site picked out is in the extreme N.W. corner of the N.E. ¼ of Section 6. If a school is built on this location, the children farthest from the school are those of Percy Cook and Edwin Cook. The former lives on the S.E. ¼ of Sec. 3, and the latter lives on the S.W. ¼ of Sec. 2. Most of the others live on Sections 1, 5, 6, 7 and 8. The South School is situated on the N.W. ¼ of Sec. 16, right on the banks of the river. The Inspector informs me that, after going into the matter very thoroughly and talking it over with the resident Missionary, Mr. Morris, they agreed that the place above mentioned is the most central location. Inspector Christianson personally went over the ground and picked out the exact location.

Proposed Peguis South Day School

Proposed Lake St. Martin Day School

Oak River Day School.

During his recent visit to the Department Mr. Indian Agent Young advised that he was completely satisfied with the work of Mr. John Robertson of Kenton, Manitoba, in erecting the Oak River School. It is therefore suggested that Mr. Robertson be approached to ascertain if he is interested in building another school for us on the same basis.

Included in our 1948-49 estimates are one-room schools and attached teachers' residences for Lake St. Martin in the Portage la Prairie Agency and Peguis South in the Fisher River Agency. It is recommended that Mr. Robertson be approached concerning these schools. They would be identical with the one he is now finishing at Oak River.

It would require two or three months to obtain the standard bill of materials for these schools. Therefore we are trying to line up our building programme now, before there is too much contracting activity.

I might add that we have found that the day labour basis of building, as adopted at Oak River, has proven cheaper than the cost plus basis contract, as used at Murdoch in the Fisher River Agency. While we have not yet the final cost...
figures, it is evident that the Oak River School will cost less than the Murdoch School (these buildings are identical).

From the map it would seem evident that Mr. Robertson would be more likely to be interested in the Lake St. Martin School rather than in the Peguis School. Therefore Mr. Lazenby should advise if there is any good carpenter interested in the Peguis School on a day labour basis.

Blueprints, specifications and bills of materials for the standard one-room school with teacher's residence are being sent, along with this letter to the two Agents concerned.

Bernard F. Healy,
Superintendent of Education.
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept' of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Proposed Peguis South Day School.

I have for acknowledgement a copy of the Department's letter of the 15th March 1948, File 136-5-5 (E), addressed to Inspector A.G. Hamilton, regarding the above noted proposed new day school.

On making enquiries locally, I find that there is no competent carpenter who could undertake the construction of this school. There was a carpenter at Fisher Branch, but he is working in Winnipeg and not available.

I wrote to Messrs Wylie & Compton, at Winnipeg, the contractors who constructed the Murdoch School last summer, and I saw Mr. Wylie when I was recently in Winnipeg. I asked Mr. Wylie if his firm would consider building the new school on a day labour basis, but he said (verbally) that they would not consider it, as they would not be able to get the labour to leave Winnipeg where they can get all the work they want.

Mr. Wylie did state that owing to the location of this new school, the cost of construction would be far less than that of Murdoch School, even if undertaken on a cost plus 10% basis.

At a meeting of the Peguis Chief and Council, held on April 6th, the matter of a site for this proposed new school was discussed, and after considerable debate, and taking into consideration the area where the most of the children live, who...
would be attending the school, the site chosen was the southwest corner of the N.W.¼ of Sec. 6, Twp. 26, R.1, W.M. on the Peguis Reserve. This particular quarter section is owned by Albert Thomas, an Indian of Peguis Band, and Councillor Andrew McPherson was delegated to see Albert Thomas, and ask him if he would have any objection to having the school built on this corner of his land. Mr. Thomas advised that he would be glad to surrender two acres of his land for school purposes at any time.

Memorandum:

MR. ALLAN,

Peguis South Indian Day School.

It is our intention to erect a new Indian Day School on the above Reserve in the Fisher River Agency.

In a recent letter to the Department, Mr. Indian Superintendent Lazenby commented as follows:

"At a meeting of the Peguis Chief and Council, held on April 6th, the matter of a site for this proposed new school was discussed, and after considerable debate, and taking into consideration the area where the most of the children live, who would be attending the school, the site chosen was the southwest corner of the N.W. ¼ of Sec. 6, Twp. 26, Rl., WRM on the Peguis Reserve. This particular quarter section is owned by Albert Thomas, an Indian of Peguis Band, and Councillor Andrew McPherson was delegated to see Albert Thomas, and ask him if he would have any objection to having the school built on this corner of his land. Mr. Thomas advised that he would be glad to surrender two acres of his land for school purposes at any time".

Could we please be advised as to the action which can be taken with regard to the surrender of the land and whether you wish it handled by your Division or by this Division.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.
Ottawa, May 6, 1948.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Poveshell South Indian Day School.

The above noted Day School is one for which the sum of $14,000.00 was included in our Main 1948-49 Estimates this year. Indian Superintendent Lazenby of the Fisher River Agency made inquiries locally and found that there are no competent carpenters who could undertake the construction of this school. He reported that there was a carpenter at Fisher Branch, but he is working in Winnipeg and not available. He also wrote to Messrs Wylie & Compton who built the Murdoch School. He reported as follows:

"I wrote to Messrs Wylie & Compton, at Winnipeg, the contractors who constructed the Murdoch School last summer, and I saw Mr. Wylie when I was recently in Winnipeg. I asked Mr. Wylie if his firm would consider building the new school on a day labour basis, but he said (verbally) that they would not consider it, as they would not be able to get the labour to leave Winnipeg where they can get all the work they want".

Mr. A.J. Doucet our Supervisor of Vocational Training was on an inspection trip of Manitoba, when he was able to contact Mr. Archibald F. McKenzie of Portage la Prairie who indicated that he would be interested in the construction of this school on a straight labour basis. We have just received Mr. McKenzie's tender by air mail and it is attached hereto. His labour tender is for $4,968.00. As you are already aware, the labour expenditure on a cost plus basis for the standard schools have been amounting to between $5,100. and $6,200. In view of the isolated locality of this school, it is felt that Mr. McKenzie's tender is fair and reasonable and is recommended for approval by the Minister.

The Contractor shall also be required to file at the same time further such further detailed information and evidence as the Minister may deem necessary in order to satisfy him that the conditions herein contained to secure the payment of fair wages have been complied with, and that the workmen so employed as aforesaid upon the portion of the work in respect of which payment is claimed have been paid in full.

(6) In the event of default being made in payment of any money owing in respect of wages of any workmen employed on the said work and if a claim therefor is filed in the office of the Minister and proof thereof satisfactory to the Minister is furnished, the Minister may order the pay such claim out of the moneys at any time payable by His Majesty under said contract and the amounts so paid shall be deemed payments to the Contractor.

(7) These conditions shall extend and apply to moneys payable for the use or hire of horses or teams, and the persons entitled to payment for the use or hire of horses or teams shall have like rights in respect of moneys so owing them as if such moneys were payable to them in respect of wages.

(8) With a view to the avoidance of any abuses which might arise from subletting, the subletting of contracts it shall be understood that subletting, other than by such as are mentioned in the trade acts, is prohibited unless the approval of the Minister is obtained. Subcontractors shall be bound in all cases to conform to the conditions of the main contract, and the main contractor shall be held responsible for strict adherence to all contract conditions on the part of subcontractor. No contract shall not be signed and no moneys thereon be transferred without the written permission of the Minister; no portion of the work to be performed shall be done at the homes of the workmen.

(9) All workmen employed upon the work comprehended in and to be executed pursuant to the said contract shall be residents of Canada, unless the Minister is of opinion that Canadian labour is not available or that other special circumstances exist which render it contrary to the public interest to enforce this provision.

Peguis South Indian Day School.

This will acknowledge receipt of Mr. B.F. Neary's letters of the 3rd and 6th instants, File 136-5-5 (E), in connection with the above noted proposed school.

In accordance with instructions contained in Mr. Neary's letter of the 6th, I am forwarding herewith in triplicate, a Requisition for the materials for this school, with a copy of the Bill of Material attached.

It will be noted that a preference is expressed for B.C. Cedar Bevel Siding.

A representative of the Provincial Department of Public Works called at the office today, and gave me permission to secure the necessary gravel and sand for this school from Provincial Crown Land, which is within four miles of the site chosen for the school.

Winnipeg firms, from whom other required materials may be purchased, are set out in the requisition.

Mr. Doucet and Mr. J. Waite called at the agency yesterday, and together we visited the Peguis Centre and Peguis South schools, and then visited the site chosen for the new school, which was approved, and the location of the building settled.

I also received instructions to immediately start the

... work ...
work of digging a well at the site, the location of which was also decided, with relation to the location of the building itself. It will be necessary to purchase direct from this office, sufficient Fir dimension lumber and nails for the cribbing of the well, and I received authority to purchase these materials from Messrs Doucet and Waite. This work will be commenced as quickly as possible.

It will of course be necessary to hire trucks for the haulage of the gravel and other materials to the site. It would therefore be appreciated if the Department would forward an accountable advance of $500.00 to take care of these expenses, in due course. The hauling of the gravel can be commenced at any time in the near future.

P.G. Lazenby,
Sup't: Fisher River Agency.

Re: Peguis new South West School.

With reference to the above, I have to report that a well has been dug close to the site of the school building, to a depth of 11 feet, and cribbed. There is a depth of 6 feet of good water. An effort was made to go deeper, but when the water was pumped out, it came back in too fast to allow further digging.

The cement, purchased by the Department has arrived, and as there was no storage room at the school site, this has been temporarily stored in a building in Hodgson, and will be hauled to the site as soon as the contractor arrives and can build a shed for it. Last night, the lumber and nails for the cement forms arrived, and is being hauled to the site today. The gravel hauling will be commenced on Monday next.

In view of the above, I today telephoned the office of the Regional Supervisor in Winnipeg, and advised that the contractor could come at any time now, and commence excavation of the basement and the construction of the forms.

We wish to refer to our REQUISITION dated July 23rd last and to the above purchase orders. Apparently, errors have occurred in the quantities required.

Re: Peguis new South West School Your file I36-9-5 (E.I)

In reply to Mr. Neary's letter of SEPT-9th the following report is being submitted on the progress of building the above mentioned school.

Basement excavated, forms put in, concrete poured and forms removed. Centre beam and joists in place. Weeping tile put in around footing, basement wall tamped with three coats to grade level and back filling completed.

Framing for walls and roof finished, shiplapped, and roof shingled. Catch basin completed, drain to sump pit put in and filled. Outside stairs and entrances nearly finished. Lap siding put on and nearing completion, rock wool insulation and shiplapping inside partly done.

We are awaiting shipment of window frames which will be installed on arrival.

In view of the amount of work that has been done the contractor Mr. McKenzie requests a further advance of $1,000.00 dollars.

Up to the present he has received $40.00 dollars.

CONTRACT AGREEMENT

THIS AGREEMENT made (in triplicate) the Twentieth day of September, in the year Nineteen Hundred and forty Eight A.D.

BETWEEN

Archibald F. McKenzie, 105 - 7th Street, S.W., Portage la Prairie, Manitoba, hereinafter called "The Contractor", of the first part;

AND His Majesty the King, represented by the Minister of Mines and Resources of Canada, hereinafter called "The Minister", of the second part,

WHEREAS the party of the first part, for the consideration hereinafter mentioned, has agreed with the party of the second part, to do, furnish and perform the work, matters and things required to be done, and performed, in the manner hereinafter described, in connection with the work or works;

NOW THIS INDENTURE WITNESSETH that the said parties hereto, hereby covenant, promise and agree, each with the other as follows:

ARTICLE I: THE covenants, clauses, provisos and conditions of the "Specifications for Standard Combined One Classroom Indian Day School with Teachers Quarters, Index No. 837", (embracing the General Conditions, Labour Conditions, General Specifications and Trade Specifications) together with the drawings and such additional detail drawings, shop drawings and instructions, as may from time to time be furnished, shall be as fully part of this Agreement as if attached hereto, or herein repeated, and should the Contractor or Minister fail to sign them, they shall nevertheless be binding on both parties.
ARTICLE II: The Contractor undertakes and agrees:

(a) to do, and perform, the works, matters and things required to be done, and performed, in connection with the following work or works namely,-

The construction of a Standard Combined One Classroom Indian Day School with Attached Teachers' Quarters (according to the drawings and specifications as prepared by the Lands and Development Services of the Department of Mines and Resources - Index No. 837) on the Peguis Indian Reserve, in the Fisher River Indian Agency, in the Province of Manitoba.

(b) to complete substantially, and to the satisfaction of the Minister, all the work, on or before the date or dates following, viz:-

the thirty first day of March, Nineteen Hundred and Forty-nine, A.D.

(c) Time shall be deemed to be material and of the essence of this contract.

ARTICLE III: The Minister undertakes and agrees, in consideration of the premises, and subject to the performance and observation on the part of the Contractor, of all covenants, provisos and conditions in the Specifications contained:

(a) To provide the materials as listed in the "Bill of Material for Standard Combined One Classroom Indian Day School with Teachers' Quarters - Index No. 837" (prepared by the Lands and Development Services Branch of the Department of Mines and Resources)
(b) To pay the Contractor in current funds, for the performance of the contract Four Thousand Nine Hundred and Sixty-eight Dollars ($4,968.00) subject to additions and deductions as provided for in the Specifications governing the work.

(c) To make progress payments on account thereof, as provided for hereunder

(i) Payment of One Thousand Dollars ($1,000.) when the main floor joists are in position,

(ii) Further payment of One Thousand Dollars ($1,000.) when the balance of framing is completed and the walls and roof are sheathed,

(iii) Further payment of One Thousand Dollars ($1,000.) when the interior work has been completed.

(d) On completion of the entire work, and on full performance of the covenants and clauses of the Specifications, to make full payment of the balance due under the Contract.

ARTICLE IV: The Contractor and the Minister for themselves, their successors, executors, administrators and assigns, hereby undertake and agree, to the full performance of the covenants contained herein.

Memorandum:

MR. NOONAN

Re: Peguis No. 1 School (Code #550).

With reference to voucher No. 1004 and your attached note, please refer to progress payment No. 1, October 8th, 1948.

On the bottom of the requisition for cheque you will find an explanation of the matter.

Philip Phelan
Chief, Education Division.

PP/MGD
Mr. McKenzie is making good progress towards completing the erection of this School. All exterior work completed including painting. There is 1 toilet however not finished as we are short of siding for it.

The interior is being painted now, walls and ceilings. We are waiting for material to complete the basement stairway. Interior finishing has not yet started, that is, the casings, trim etc.,

We are today getting in touch with the Furnace Contractor re getting the Furnace in. (We are hoping to get him to repair the Fisher River School furnace while he is here.) We are also ordering a sink and indoor toilet, these do not appear on any of the purchase orders, although the sink is listed in the specifications.

In Mr. Neary's letter 550-5 (E 1) October 20th last, the $2968, accountable advance has not arrived. This is the balance of this contract. The next $1,000 will of course, not be advanced to Mr. McKenzie until he has completed the interior work.

Mr. McKenzie is making a good job of this building, it looks attractive and we are pleased to be able to report favourably on it.

cc for Mr. Davis, Wpg.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6249, file 550-5, part 1)
Re Peguis #1 Indian Day School (S-W)

Mr. McKenzie, Contractor, for the above mentioned School left for his home on the 23rd of December 1948. Up to date the uncompleted work is as follows: (1) Painting toilets last coat; (2) painting outside landing and steps; (3) Painting concrete floor in basement.

As the weather for doing this work is too cold this finishing had to be left until next spring. Mr. McKenzie promised the undersigned that he would return for the required time to complete same in May or June when so requested. The remainder would require approximately 2 days to complete.

Mr. Waite, Field Agent from the Winnipeg Office inspected the building and found all work satisfactory and up to specifications.

It is requested, that authority be granted to this Office to pay Mr. McKenzie in full as his agreement calls for, and leave it to his honor to return for the two days required to fulfill his Agreement. He still has an unpaid balance of $968.00 coming to him.

In view of the excellent job Mr. McKenzie has done and since it is hoped to retain his services for next year, we recommend the above.

S. Boyne, A/Supt

We wish to refer to Mr. Neary's letter of the 20th instant file 550-5 (El) regarding the balance due to Mr. Mackenzie on his labour for Erecting Peguis #1 School Contract.

On November 1st last, we received an accountable advance of $2 968.00 being the amount due on the contract, and have since paid him $2 000.00 leaving a balance of $968.00 due which we have here.

In our letter of the 5th instant, we requested authority to pay Mr. McKenzie in full, in view of the fact that, some work was not yet completed, although, Mr. McKenzie has promised to do this as soon as the weather is suitable.

We would be pleased therefore, to have Departmental authority to pay Mr. McKenzie in full, which we recommend, which will be followed with a Labour Return and a Credit Voucher.

S Boyne
A/Supt

c.c. Mr. Davis, WINNIPEG.

Mr. S. Boyne,
A/Supt., Indian Agency,

The Treasury Branch takes exception in making payments of such large amounts. Advances for labour are actually intended to be used only when labour is being employed for short periods, and consequently, require their money when their work is completed.

Dear Colonel Neary,

We have supplied Tenders for the Indian Day School and Teacherage at Peguis #2, #3 and #4, also for the Long Plain Indian Reserve. In our Tender we estimated that we could have these schools completed and ready for operation on the first of September. It was hoped at that time that the contracts would be awarded within ten days of the closing of the Tender.

This letter is to enquire if a decision has been made and if not, will it be made by July 1st? If it is made on July 1st or after, we shall have to ask for an extension of time necessary for the completion of the contract, if it is awarded to us.

Mr. Davis in a conversation advised us that a similar unit was proposed to be constructed this year at Rosburn Indian Reserve. I had an occasion to be in that area and have examined this site. Afterwards I called on Mr. Smith, your Agent at Birtle, to find out when the advertisement for Tender was to be posted. He was of the opinion that it should now be advertised, but had not seen it himself. On checking his correspondence, I observed that the school was proposed for September, 1950. However he reiterated that he understood from Major Clark and Mr. Davis that this school was to be completed in 1949. Could you kindly advise us in this respect?

Mr. Davis also mentioned another school for Fort Alexander Indian Reserve. We would be definitely interest in tendering on this project also. May we be advised of your wishes in this matter.

If these schools contracts are to be awarded to us, we are now in an immediate position to start operations, and can
assure you of our very close co-operation and attention to the matter. We could easily handle all the sites mentioned in the preceding paragraphs, this summer, and have the schools finished for operation early in the school year, but we would like to get started on the operation as early in July as possible.

I am enclosing Plan 66-1 and 46-1 thinking that you may have some idea of proposing Indian Homes. A re-arrangement of the partitions shown on the plan could be made on the site for the individual requirements. A sketch showing a cross-section of the construction detail of the unit is also attached. This is an economy-type of dwelling using a minimum amount of materials. We would be pleased to include any additional material that is deemed advisable by your Department, such as shiplap, sheathing on the exterior of the wall studs under the siding. The partitions are 7'6" in height to allow free circulation of the air from the stove. With the basic unit we supply a 4' sink unit with a drain extending through the wall and the necessary amount of paint for each building. Our price on the present plan is $1179.35 for Plan 66-1 and $897.35 for Plan 46-1. These prices are quoted f.o.b. Winnipeg, and other erection extras are supplying the erector his travelling and living expenses. Freight charges could be made directly to your Department by the transportation companies or your own arrangements could be carried out.

Thanking you for your kindness and co-operation, and trusting that we may hear from you at your earliest convenience, we are,

Yours very truly,

NORTH AMERICAN BUILDINGS LIMITED

C.J.C./J
ENCS.

C.J. Connelly
Engineer

Dear Colonel Neary:

Re: Schools.

We wish to acknowledge with thanks your signal of July 13th advising the award of contract for Peguis Indian Day Schools to our Company. Mr. Davis has previously sent us a memorandum on this subject.

As you are probably aware, cement is in difficult supply at the present moment and it would facilitate us greatly if we could be advised, if there are other schools likely to be advertised for contracts in the near future. The purpose of this information is to advise the manufacturer of the amount of cement we may require this summer, if we are fortunate to obtain other school contracts.

You already have our tender to build on contract the Long Plains Indian School, near Portage La Prairie. In discussing the matter of schools with Mr. Davis and other officials in this province of your department, there was some indication that it was likely that day schools for Indians may be built at Rosburn, Fort Alexander and Roseau River. We would be pleased to have information on this matter in order to pass it along to the manufacturer so that he may be alerted to the probable needs of cement for your projects. Each building requires 285 to 300 bags of cement and upwards to 60 yds. of gravel plus reinforcing iron for the foundation walls.

We will appreciate receiving this information at your earliest possible date.

Dear Mr. Marsh:

Your monthly day school returns for the months of April and May 1949 have been received and contents of your accompanying letter noted.

It appears that you are uncertain as to the meaning of section 17 of the return. May we clarify this matter for you.

Section 6 refers to the number of pupils who actually attended school during some part of the month. If any children are absent during the whole month, they will not be included in either section mentioned above.

We trust this information will be helpful to you in completing monthly returns in the future, and we are again enclosing your April and May returns for correction.

To the Indian Commissioner Dear Sir,

I received your letter not very long ago & what I say the last time I wrote to you did not take it & I'm not very glad about it. I didn't think you would say what you told me in your letter so hoping will do your best to help me this time we are 414, here doing the same thing in Clear water lake & I don't know what to do with these & I want you to help me with them what do, for we are not so rich as the white people to bring all.
The children away, where so far away where they should go. In this reserve, one of the priest came here to me not long ago & he said me in here and three men start off to commence this by my name they went out to pine creek & I made that letter over there to send it to you. I'm quite very old man & since the treaty commenced I have been the chief and up today we took you to help us for we want the school here. I would be very glad to see my old children going to school be for I die, we have finish a school house already & we want to put a teacher for the children.
or else if you want me to try and find a teacher I can do it & I will all the men will pay the teacher if you don't want to pay for us & hoping you will do your best for us & Commission work with the Great Good wishes so good bye may God will help us answers soon Yours Truly

P.S. Baptiste Bone these men that handing this letter to you let them say whatever they wish to say to you

MEMO FOR SCHOOL BRANCH.

The accompanying letter from Baptiste Bone, one of the leading Indians settled at Clear Water Lake, the fishing station of Keesekooowenin's Band of Birtle Agency, asking for the opening of a Day School on said fishing reserve, on reconsidering my reply to Mr. Bone on 23rd February last, as shown on file 126/G of the Indian Commissioner's Office, appears to me now worthy of support, or at least of a fair trial. It is true Mr. Agent Wheatley in his report of 18th February, in reply to my enquiry, said the Department should not open a school at this point. But on 16th March a deputation of the principal Indians of the reserve waited on me at Winnipeg, with a letter from Baptiste Bone, and a paper dated 13th March, signed by the heads of families on the reserve, promising to send their children regularly to school if they were allowed a Teacher. Further, according to Mr. Bone's letter of the 1st April, the Indians there have erected a school house at their own expense, and engaged a teacher.

Such zeal, I think, should be encouraged, and I therefore now recommend that the usual $75.00 per quarter be paid the Teacher they have employed, beginning on the 1st of April last; and that the grant be continued to the school if the attendance and teacher are satisfactory. If the teacher prove incompetent, no doubt another can be found.

Sir,

Mr. Laird has transferred a letter received by him from Baptiste Bone, one of the Indians of the Keesekocowin band settled at Clear Water Lake, with reference to the payment of the teacher's salary at the school which has been established at Clear Water Lake.

To encourage the Indians in their efforts to procure an education for their children, the Department has decided that it will provide a salary of $300.00 per annum from April 1, last, payment to be made upon receipt of the usual returns.

This grant is conditional on the attendance being sufficient to justify the continuance of the school, and the present teacher's engagement is only to be temporary. Her remaining on will depend upon the results obtained as shown by the reports of yourself and the Inspector.

Sir,

Referring to your letter of May 22nd, 1909,

with reference to the Day school recently opened at the Fishing Station Clear Water Lake, Keesekocowenin's Band I have the honor to inform you that on the 9th Instant this school was inspected; the Inspector Mr. S.J. Jackson, being present. There were 8 pupils present, 4 boys and 4 girls, ages ranged from 5 years to 12. All the pupils present were neatly and comfortably clad and very clean and seemed under control of the teacher Miss Mary Neshotah, an ex-pupil of the Pine Creek Boarding school. She had been 8 years at school and graduated about four years ago. There are 11 on the Roll and the average attendance from the 1st of April last to June 9th was 9.3 a splendid attendance compared to the Oknase Day school. The older girls and boys were able to read the simple Lesson cards fairly well and the younger ones knew their letters perfectly. None of the pupils had attended any school before April 1st last. The teacher deserves credit for the advancement made and no doubt she will do for the present, but it will be necessary if the school is to be carried on permanently, that a more qualified teacher be employed.

Sir:

George McKay and Baptiste Mekis, accompanied by Rev. Father Comeau as interpreter, waited upon me the other day.

They handed me to read a paper signed by George McKay on the 1st April, 1909, in the presence of the Indian Agent, in which he agreed to give for three years free the use of a building owned by him on the Clear Water Lake Reserve for a day school for the Catholic children of the Reserve, the Department to bear the expense of putting the building in good repair.

They also handed me to read a letter from you to George McKay, dated the 29th June, 1909, file 343,039, expressing pleasure at the success of the school and promising to assist in its maintenance.

They complained that notwithstanding that the school was established as a Catholic school, and is so recognized by the Department, George Bone, Chief of the Riding Mountain Reserve, visits the school nearly every Sunday, when the Catholic Indians are gathered for religious devotions, and insists on conducting what they described as a Protestant service consisting of preaching by the said George Bone, bible reading, praying, and the singing of hymns.

They represented that there are about forty Indians in residence on the Clear Water Lake Reserve, and that all but four old people are Catholics.

They asked that George Bone be officially prohibited from interfering with the Sunday meetings of the Catholic Indians.
Indians in their school house for religious devotions.

They expressed deep interest in the education of the children of the Reserve, and an anxiety that the Catholic school, which was established on their initiative should be maintained as a Catholic school and officially secure from any interference on the part of George Bone.

They would be grateful if the Department would furnish the school with a bell that could be heard by children residing two miles distant from the school, and thus ensure their prompter attendance.

They represented that the school was quite short of biscuits, only nine boxes being supplied. They calculate that at least sixteen boxes a year are required. The attendance, they stated, averages between nine and eleven.

I promised to bring their representations to the attention of the Department.

During the course of the interview they referred to other matters not appertaining to the school, and these I am bringing to the attention of Mr. Inspector Jackson.

Dear Sir,

I have for acknowledged receipt your favor of the 7th inst., regarding my request for parochial school on Clearwater Lake Reserve.

Sir:-

as stated before if you think

OTTAWA, August 29th, 1922.

Sir -

With further reference to your letter of the 7th instant, regarding the continuing of the parochial school which was in operation on the Clearwater Lake Reserve this summer, I beg to say that it is not the intention of the Department to continue this school during the coming year. A number of the children who attended while the school was in operation were pupils of the Birtle Boarding School who were on their summer vacation. These children will all be returned to that school. All children of school age on the Clearwater Reserve can very well attend a residential school conducted under the auspices of the religious denomination to which they belong.

With reference to your remarks regarding conditions at the Birtle Boarding School, I beg to say that no reliance is placed in your complaint that the pupils, after eight years' tuition, are unable to write their names.

Regarding the farm instructor, it is considered that any information which you have as to the work he is performing was obtained from the pupils. He is a faithful worker, and doing his best to give the boys a good training along the lines of farming and the caring of stock.

We understand that you do not reside on the Clearwater Lake Reserve, but live at the Fishing Station, and that you have neglected your work as Chief and do not attend important meetings of the Band. We also understand that you hold land on both Reserves and that last year you neglected to summer fallow your land, and some of the other Indians had to cut down the woods, and, as a consequence, the Agent gave permission to Gilbert Bone to have the land which you had neglected put in crop.

It is expected that, as Chief, you will show a better example to the other Indians and perform the duties of your office satisfactorily. You should also encourage the Indian parents to send their children to residential schools, where they will receive a good education, as there is no likelihood of the day school on the Clearwater Lake Reserve being reopened.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Chief Geo. Bone,
Erickson,
Man.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 13th instant, appealing against the decision of our representative at Birtle, in which he refused you permission to hold parochial school on the Clear Water Lake Reserve.

Dear Doctor Dorey:-

Indian Agent Waite advises that there are approximately twenty children of school age on the Long Plain Reserve who should be attending school, but there is no accommodation for them in the Portage la Prairie School.

In view of the above condition, the agent makes the following suggestion,-

"There is a Mission house on the reserve and it has been suggested that this be used as a temporary day school. The Mission residence adjoins the Mission house and arrangements could be made for the teacher to room and board at this home. The Mission is under the direction of the United Church and they would have to be approached and permission obtained in regard to using the Mission. The resident Missionary has no objection, in fact the suggestion came through him."

Long Plain Reserve - Proposed School

Upon receipt of your letter of file 6-37 of April 10, we wrote to Dr. G. Dorey, Secretary, Board of Home Missions, United Church of Canada. He visited this office on May 3 and discussed the situation at Long Plain. He is quite willing to have the Department rent the mission building as a temporary day school. He has further requested that you consult the missionary concerned and come to an agreement as to the rent per month which would be suitable for such classroom accommodation.

When we get this information, the necessary arrangements can be made to ship desks, blackboards and other school supplies as needed to this location. We can also consider the employment of a teacher for 1947-48.

MAY 9 1947

PUBLIC ARCHIVES CANADA
In reply to the above noted letter, I wish to advise that I interviewed the Missionary on the Long Plain Reserve on the 19th instant, relative to renting the Mission House for a Day School. On the 20th, a telephone call was received from Mr. Best, D.D., Winnipeg, saying that he was proceeding to Long Plain Reserve on the 22nd, and made an appointment to call at the Agency Office on his return with the intention of discussing the matter.

Doctor Best intimated that the rental should be $35.00 per month, but claimed he had no idea what the rental charge should be, and I proposed $20.00 per month. He claimed that he would have to write Doctor Dory concerning the matter and would suggest a rental somewhere between the two figures. The matter will have to lay over until such time as the matter is referred to Doctor Dory.

Some work will have to be done on the building. I beg to suggest that the ceiling be insulated with two ply of heavy building paper and shavings. A four inch partition should be erected between the mission and the house portion, to deaden noise from the school. A larger heater will have to be purchased, and two toilets erected for the children. If it is possible, would suggest that the walls of the building be also insulated.

Doctor Best suggested a two year term and then the matter to be reviewed again.
Further particulars will be forwarded the Department as soon as the rent question is satisfactorily settled.

I hesitate to estimate on the cost of the work on the building. Carpenters are not available in the district, although I believe there are Indians on the reserve who are quite capable of effecting repairs of the nature outlined.

J. Weite,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, 3rd June, 1947.

I beg to refer to the above noted letter, in which the teacher of the Long Plain Reserve was allowed $12.00 per month in lieu of residence. At that time the arrangement was that she would live at the Mission on the reserve and adjoining the school. Since school was first opened, she has lived at the Farm Instructor's residence on the reserve. First, because the room at the mission was not ready for her; later because the missionary's wife was pregnant and would in the near future have to go to hospital. It now appears that the teacher's room is not likely to be made available this year and the teacher claims she is somewhat afraid of the missionary.

The object in writing is to be advised if the $12.00 allowed monthly would be payable to the Farm Instructor. The house is Government property and I hesitate forwarding vouchers in favour of the Farm Instructor until advised by the Department.

Ottawa, June 15th, 1948.

Dear Sir,

The Superintendent of Indian education has referred to us a requisition from Miss Victoria Gerega, the teacher of Long Plain Indian Day School, Edwin, Manitoba, for 168 pounds of cod liver oil, 3000 vitamin pills and two boxes of tongue depressors. Before any action is taken on this order, would you please advise how many pupils are to be served. The quantity, approximately 17 gallons of cod liver oil substitute, seems considerable especially at this time of year when the use of it usually diminishes during the summer period. Does this school not close about the end of June and, if so, could not the oil be sent when it re-opens. Any other information that will enable us to deal intelligently with this request will be appreciated.

Yours truly,

W. L. Falconer, M.D.
Assistant Director,
Indian Health Services.
