October 12, 1948

Re: Long Plain Matters

1. The Hutterite Lease Proposal

Decided to go ahead and take the surrender from the Band as soon as possible, covering approximately (960 acres & 640 & 500) - 1300 acres. Then negotiate release with Hutterites.

2. Re Forsley lease - application to buy -
(a) Decided not to sell at all
(b) Decided to let the leases (Forsley-Sylvester) run out and then return the balance of the surrendered land to the Long Plain Res. #6.

3. Re Section 8 - Long Plain Sioux

Decided to lease a half section either the North or East halves under 95-3 of the Act and compensate any Indian occupant at the rate of $1.00 per acre per year for any cultivated land out of the existing Band funds until rents begin to come in and thereafter out of rents. No surrender considered necessary.

4. Band Farm

Decided to try to develop either Section 17 or 20 as a Band Farm. Equipment - power and machinery to be purchased out of Band funds. To be repaid out of profits over a term of years (say 5).

5. Day School

To be located on the South-west corner of the south-east quarter of Section 20 - 2 acres. The Band will have to be asked to surrender 2 acres for administrative purposes.

Advantages of suggested location -
(a) Most central point in relation to population
(b) One mile from Reserve No. 6
(c) Three miles from Martin P.O. and village
(d) One mile from church (present school)
(e) Within easy reach of Long Plain Sioux children

D. J. Allan,
Superintendent, Reserves & Trusts.

R. E. Davis,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies.
October 21, 1948.

Major G.A.F. Clark,
c/o Mr. J.P.B. Ostrander,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,
304 Post Office Building,
REGINA, Saskatchewan.

Long Plain Indian Day School.

Dear Major Clark:

One of the Indian day schools which we intend to build next year in Manitoba is at Long Plain. This reserve is in the Portage la Prairie Superintendentcy and we have successfully conducted a day school in the United Church. In view of the satisfactory attendance, we intend to build a standard school and teachersage. I would appreciate your visiting this reserve when in Manitoba and check the school site already selected by Mr. Allan and Mr. Davis. My information on this site is as follows:-

"To be located on the south-west corner of the south-east quarter of Section 20 - 2 acres. The Band will have to be asked to surrender 2 acres for administrative purposes.

"Advantages of suggested location -

(a) Most central point in relation to population
(b) One mile from Reserve H.Q.
(c) Three miles from Edwin P.O. and village
(d) One mile from Church (present school)
(e) Within easy reach of Long Plain Sioux children."

Yours sincerely,

Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.

Re: Long Plain School

This will confirm our night letter of today's date as follows:

SURRENDER UNNECESSARY STOP ALL WE REQUIRE IS A BAND COUNCIL RESOLUTION SETTING APART DESCRIBED TWO ACRES FOR USE OF THE DEPARTMENT FOR SCHOOL PURPOSES FOR SO LONG AS REQUIRED FOR THAT PURPOSE.

While at one time it was considered that surrenders were required for those portions of Indian Reserves to be used for administrative purposes, it has now been decided that such action would not be correct for the administration, and particularly the school divisions would then be spending funds allotted by Parliament for Indian education on lands not within the boundaries of Indian Reserves.

The practice to be followed in these cases is simply to have the Band Council pass a resolution setting aside a described area of the Reserve for the use of the Department for school purposes for so long as the said area is used for that purpose, which, in effect, means that the Department has the right to use the property so long as a school is operated thereon, but should the school be discontinued for any reason, the property immediately becomes available to the Council for location in the same manner as other common lands of the Band.
It is not known whether in the present case, any Indian improvements are effected. If so, it is customary to arrange for the individual Indian in question to agree to sell his improvements on the desired area to his Band at whatever price is agreed on, the monies for the purchase being provided by the Department.

D. J. Allan,
Superintendent,
Reserves and Trusts.

TO HIS EXCELLENCY

THE GOVERNOR GENERAL IN COUNCIL

The undersigned has the honour to report:

THAT the Indian Affairs Branch of the Department of Mines and Resources has provided for the construction of a one-room Indian Day School and attached teacher's residence on the Long Plain Indian Reserve, in the Portage La Prairie Agency, Province of Manitoba, for the education of the Indian children living there;

THAT, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Act, tenders have been advertised for in local and trade newspapers;

THAT we have received, as a result of these advertisements, the following two tenders:

North American Buildings, Limited,
Winnipeg, Manitoba ........... $11,668.71

Manitoba Engineering Company, Limited,
Winnipeg, Manitoba .......... $13,633.00

THAT the above tenders have been examined by Departmental officials and it is found that they comply with the conditions outlined on tender forms which had been prepared by the Indian Affairs Branch and the plans and specifications as prepared by the Lands and Development Services Branch;

THAT Departmental officials recommend the acceptance of the lower tender, namely that of North American Buildings, Limited, Winnipeg, Manitoba, in an amount of Eleven Thousand Six Hundred and Forty-eight Dollars and Seventy-one Cents ($11,668.71);

THAT funds are available for this purpose in Vote 230, 1949-50, Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources.

The undersigned, therefore, recommends the acceptance of the tender of North American Buildings, Limited, Winnipeg, Manitoba, for the erection of this one-room school and teacher's residence, for the amount of Eleven Thousand Six Hundred and Forty-eight Dollars and Seventy-one Cents ($11,668.71).

Respectfully submitted,

Minister of Mines and Resources.

The Committee of the Privy Council have had before them a report dated 8th July, 1949, from the Minister of Mines and Resources, representing:

THAT the Indian Affairs Branch of the Department of Mines and Resources has provided for the construction of a one-room Indian Day School and attached teacher's residence on the Long Plain Indian Reserve, in the Portage la Prairie Agency, Province of Manitoba, for the education of the Indian children living there;

THAT, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Act, tenders have been advertised for in local and trade newspapers with the following results:

North American Buildings, Limited,
Winnipeg, Manitoba.................. $11,648.71
Bolton Construction Company, Ltd.,
Winnipeg, Manitoba................... 12,820.00
Manitoba Engineering Company, Ltd.,
Winnipeg, Man........................ 13,833.00
Joe's & Company, Limited,
Winnipeg, Man......................... 16,150.00

THAT the above tenders have been examined by Departmental officials and it is found that they comply with the conditions outlined on tender forms which had been prepared by the Indian Affairs Branch and the plans and specifications as prepared by the Lands and Development Services Branch;

THAT Departmental officials recommend the acceptance of the lowest tender, namely that of North American Buildings, Limited, Winnipeg, Manitoba, in an amount of $11,648.71; and

THAT funds are available for this purpose in Vote 230, 1949-50, Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources.

The Committee, therefore, on the recommendation of the Minister of Mines and Resources, advise that authority be granted to accept the tender of North American Buildings, Limited, Winnipeg, Manitoba, for the erection of the said one-room school and teacher's residence, for the amount of $11,648.71.

Dear Mr. Simms:

I have read your memorandum on the new Long Plain School and can certainly appreciate your feelings.

Last year and the year before, we built schools with full basements and furnaces and with provision, where hydro was available, for flush toilets. You have probably seen one such school at Oak River.

Our building costs kept mounting to such an extent that we were forced to curtail our building program, so we had our architects plan a much cheaper building which could be built easily and which could at a later date have a small unit added on to provide for forced hot air heating and for flush toilets.

In other words, we were thinking exactly on lines such as yours and have built accordingly. At the time the Long Plain school was planned, hydro was not available and Mr. Hamilton reported that he expected it possibly this year to within one mile of the proposed school site. I have heard nothing further from him concerning the hydro and your memorandum was the first intimation that it had arrived on the reserve.

There is no school on the Crane River reserve. We operated a Day School there for years, and it was closed up three years ago. I believe there are about 20 children of school age on the reserve. Some of the children, as you will remember, were sent to Elkhorn three years ago, and when they went home did not return to the school. I was there two years ago, in company with Mr. Eley, and it was our intention to take them back to the school, but my impression at that time was that they were not physically fit to go to Elkhorn. It must be taken into consideration that the principal food of these people is fish. I am not a medical man, but I am under the impression that getting away from the lake and being fed entirely different food does not agree with them. A few children from there are attending the Pine Creek School.

Ottawa, November 4th, 1924.

Sir:

Replying to your letter of the 31st ultimo, I beg to inform you that the Department will discontinue its share of the cost of the expenses in conducting the Crane River combined white and Indian day school from June 30th, last, the end of the last school year. The last payment made was for the quarter ended December 31st, 1923. If you will forward a statement, in duplicate, of the cost of conducting this school during the March and June quarters, 1924, a cheque in payment of one-third, our share of the cost, will be forwarded. We have received returns showing the attendance during these two quarters. We understand that this school was closed from July 1st to September 30th.

Our local Indian Agent informs us that he is taking steps to have the Indian children of school age at Crane River placed in the Elkhorn Indian Residential School.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Dear Sir,

re School at Crane River

The school building on the reserve at Crane River is absolutely unfit for use and the Indians will not enter it nor will they permit their children to enter it as they fear it will collapse if there should come a little extra gale of wind. The teacher has secured the loan of a house from an Indian who may return at any time, and if he should return and ask for his house we will have no place for the school.

I have just had an independent report on the whole situation and believe that a proper school building should be provided without delay in the interests of the work there. As the building will be on the reserve it should be provided by the Indian Department.

MEMORANDUM.

Mr. Scott,-

With reference to the letter from Mr. Fletcher, Deputy Minister of Education for the Province of Manitoba, regarding the school at Crane River and claiming that this Department should provide a new building, I beg to say that this is a joint school, the Provincial Government paying two-thirds of the cost and this Department one-third.

School is held in a building loaned by an Indian, the old school building being, as Mr. Fletcher states, unfit for use.

Mr. Agent Ogletree was written to in reference to the erection of a new building a year ago and informed that, if it was decided to put up a new building, the Department was not prepared to pay the total cost of the lumber, etc., that would be required to finish it, the Indians being prepared to furnish the logs. Mr. Ogletree replied that the building where the school is now held is large enough for the number of children attending, and the Indians have consented to do with this building; and that he did not consider a new building necessary at present.

The teacher, in his report for the year ended the 31st of December, last, states as follows:- "I have been teaching on the Reserve here; in a temporary school building since Feb. 17, 1918, and find myself hampered for want of room. We have made application for the building of a new school, but so far in vain. So it is absolutely that we have a new building in the near future, for the present accommodation will not be good enough in two or three years time".

Since the school was opened in February, 1918, they have had an average attendance of Indian children of seven and about the same number of whites. The present teacher
teacher, judging by his report, is efficient, and the Department's share of maintaining the school for ten months came to $302.00, and $350.00 should cover the yearly cost. This is a satisfactory arrangement as far as the Department is concerned and, if funds could be spared, I would suggest that Mr. Ogletree be asked to give an estimate of what it would cost to supply the necessary lumber, etc., to put up a building. Sometime ago he stated that it would take about $250.00 to finish the building, the Indians supplying the logs and doing the work.

Indian Affairs Branch,

Re: Crane River School - Dauphin Agency.

When I visited the above mentioned school recently, six girls and six boys - a total of twelve pupils - were in attendance; and I understand that if the school was larger, about four more pupils would attend, who are presently in boarding school.

This school, as you are aware, is held in an old building rented from the Church, and the teacher is living in a log building. The school was very tidy and well managed, and the children seemed to be making very good progress.

A new school should be built at this point next year. However, I do not feel it would warrant putting up one of our new schools, and would recommend that, if possible, logs be taken out this winter for building a school and teacher's residence. The Indians could do most of the work; and state that they would work reasonably and do their share in constructing the school and buildings - as they are very anxious to have them. I consider that a school built this way - by getting logs out during the winter; having lumber sawn for the floors and roof; and hiring a carpenter, who would be assisted by the Indians - should not cost us more than $6,500.00.

I would very much like to hear from you regarding the above and if money could be made available for part of the building - in order that the logs could be taken out this winter, it would provide the Indians with work and also get the school started.

R.S. Davis
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Grass River Indian Day School.

Included in our Supplementary Estimates is the sum of $5,000.00 for the erection of a log school and teachers' quarters on this isolated reserve in the Dauphin Indian Superintendency, Manitoba.

As you are aware, we do not feel that it is justified to expend twelve to fourteen thousand dollars in erecting frame buildings on the smaller and isolated reserves such as Grass River. Therefore, we have developed a standard log building which will provide suitable accommodation for many of these smaller reserves on which a frame building would be an expensive project.

Mr. Davis, the Regional Supervisor, has recommended that we hire Mr. Joe Thomas, an Indian carpenter and log man of the Peguis Reserve as foreman for the construction of this school. The logs are being cut and the insulation, millwork, paint, etc., are being ordered by the Departmental Purchasing Agent. I would recommend, therefore, that you approve the hiring of Mr. Joe Thomas as foreman for the erection of this school, at the rate of $1.25 per hour.

Director.

Privy Council
Canada

The Committee of the Privy Council have had before them a report, dated 6th July, 1947, from the Acting Minister of Mines and Resources, representing:

That it is immediately necessary and funds are provided in the 1947-48 Estimates, Indian Affairs Branch, Mines and Resources, to construct a combined one-room Indian Day School and Teacher's Residence and a Residence for the Indian Agency Clerk on the Fisher River Indian Reserve, Fisher River Indian Agency in the Province of Manitoba;

That it is essential that educational facilities be provided for Indian children on the Fisher River Indian Reserve and living quarters for the Indian Day School Teacher;

That it is also essential that a residence for the Indian Agency Clerk be provided before the school term begins as the Clerk has been living for the last few years in the house provided for the School Teacher of the Peguis Day School resulting in the closing of the Peguis Day School in the Fisher River Agency. Funds are available as follows:

Indian Education - Vote 181 - Construction of Indian Day School and Teacher's Residence, Fisher River Reserve..........................$8,000.00

Indian Agencies - Vote 178 - Construction of residence for Indian Agency Clerk....................$10,000.00

That Section 36 of the Public Works Act, Chapter 166, Revised Statutes of Canada, 1927, provides in part, as follows:

"Whenever any works are to be executed under the direction of any Department of the Government the Minister having charge of such Department shall invite tenders by public advertisement for the execution of such works except in cases (a) of pressing emergency in which delay would be injurious to the public interest...";

That efforts have been made to interest builders and contractors in the City of Winnipeg and local towns near the said reserve but the builders and contractors have advised that they would not be interested in tenders, if invited as aforesaid, as they have all the work they can do in their own localities;

The Honourable
the Minister of Mines and Resources.

That a competent building contractor of Swan Lake, Manitoba, whose work is known to the Department as being satisfactory, has agreed to undertake the construction of the said building immediately for One Dollar and Fifty Cents ($1.50) per hour plus board and transportation;

That it is considered that the construction of these buildings is a pressing emergency and is within the exception provided in Section 38, above recited, and, further, it is considered that the work can be more expeditiously and economically executed as suggested herein.

The Committee, therefore, on the recommendation of the Acting Minister of Mines and Resources, advise that authority be granted for the construction of these two buildings as outlined above, this being the only arrangement possible at the present time and it being essential that both these works be undertaken at once and carried to completion in order that the buildings will be available for use by the time the next school term commences.

Privy Council Canada

The Committee of the Privy Council have had before them a report dated 31st July, 1947, from the Acting Minister of Mines and Resources, representing:

That it is immediately necessary and funds are provided in the 1947-48 Estimates, Indian Affairs Branch, Mines and Resources, to construct a combined one-room Indian Day School and Teacher's residence, and a residence for the Indian Agency Clerk, Fisher River Indian Reserve; Fisher River Indian Agency, in the Province of Manitoba;

That it is essential that educational facilities be provided for Indian children on the Fisher River Reserve and living quarters for the Indian Day School Teacher;

That it is also essential that a residence for the Indian Agency Clerk be provided before the school term begins as the Clerk has been living for the last few years in the house provided for the school teacher of the Peguis Day School resulting in the closing of the Peguis Day School in the Fisher River Agency;

That funds are available as follows:

Indian Education - Vote 161 - Construction of Indian Day School and Teacher's residence, Fisher River Reserve. $8,000.00

Indian Agencies - Vote 178 - Construction of residence for Indian Agency Clerk. $10,000.00

That Section 56 of the Public Works Act, Chapter 166, R.S.C. 1927, provides, in part, as follows:

"Whenever any works are to be executed under the direction of any Department of the Government the Minister having charge of such Department shall invite tenders by public advertisement for the execution of such works except in cases (a) of pressing emergency in which delay would be injurious to the public interest......."

That efforts have been made to interest builders and contractors in the City of Winnipeg and local towns near the said reserve but no one was interested in tendering, if invited as aforesaid, as they had all the work they could do in their own localities;

That a competent building contractor, from whom an offer was received, refused the work as he had contracted to do more than he could possibly carry out;

The Honourable

The Minister of Mines and Resources.
(Authority to engage this man and to pay him at the rate of $1.50 per hour plus board and travelling expenses was secured under P.C. 2908 dated July 15, 1947);

That further efforts have been made resulting in an offer from Messrs. Wylie and Compton, Contractors, Winnipeg, to undertake the work on a cost plus 10% basis, plus transportation of personnel from Winnipeg, board and lodging of the men as cost items and overtime of two hours per day per man at the rate of time and one-half for overtime;

That the firm of Messrs. Wylie and Compton of Winnipeg are known to be reliable and in view of the isolated locality it will be necessary to allow them the charges mentioned, otherwise they will not be able to induce skilled tradesmen to go to the Fisher River Agency to undertake the work;

That in addition to the two jobs mentioned above a small powerhouse building has to be erected, and on the same terms and conditions Wylie and Compton will also undertake this work, the cost of which is to be chargeable to Indian Affairs Branch, Vote 173, and the Department of National Health and Welfare, Vote 225;

That it is considered that the construction of these buildings is a pressing emergency and is within the exception provided in Section 36 above recited and further, it is considered that the work can be more expeditiously and economically executed as suggested herein.

The Committee, therefore, on the recommendation of the Acting Minister of Mines and Resources, advise that authority be granted for the construction of the said buildings this being the only arrangement possible at the present time and it being essential that all of these works be undertaken at once and carried to completion in order that the buildings will be available for use by the time the next school term commences.

The Committee further advise that Order in Council P.C. 2908, dated July 15th, 1947, be and it is hereby rescinded.

A. D. P. Heaney,
Clerk of the Privy Council

Re: New School - Fisher River Reserve.

I beg to advise that work on the above project has been considerably held up of late on account of heavy rains. The excavation however, is well on to completion.

With regard to the gravel required for the cement work I have to report that it has been found impossible to procure this from the location originally chosen, owing to the fact that no truck could reach the place as the ground is now very soft and boggy. It is very doubtful if even teams could get there with wagons, and even if they did, they could not haul half a load. In consequence of this, the only place left to procure the gravel (100 yards approx:) is the Provincial Government's stockpile, from where we got the gravel for the power house, and the new Clerk's House, 4½ miles south of Hodgson. However, this is 28 miles from the new school site, and the total cost of the gravel hauled from here, would be $4.50 per yard; 80¢ per yard payable to the Provincial Government, and $4.00 per yard for trucking. I trust that this will have the approval of the Department. I already have the Provincial Government's permission to remove the above gravel from their stockpile.

P.G. Lazenby
Indian Agent.

Mr. P.G. Lazenby, Indian Agent,
Hodgson, Manitoba.

We have your letter of the 27th instant in which you advise that the new day school on the Fisher River Reserve is almost completed. No arrangements have yet been made to purchase the equipment required either for the school or teacher's residence. Please forward a requisition for the equipment you consider necessary.

You should note that desks are made in three sizes; large, medium and small.

As you are aware, we already have a school on the Fisher River Reserve known as "Fisher River Day School". For the new school we would like to use some different name if possible as experience shows that if we have two schools of the same name on the same reserve, there is always considerable confusion in filing correspondence and referring to the school.

Please let me know what name you would suggest that we use for the new school.

I wish to report as follows in connection with the new Murdoch Indian Day School building, which was built during the past summer on the Fisher River Reserve:

After the completion of this building, I did not visit it again until after several weeks had passed, but when I did visit it, on my way to Fisher River, I found all the walls, ceilings, cupboards both inside and outside, covered thickly with frost; probably a half inch thick. I was at a loss for a time to know just what to do about this condition, but finally decided to use clean new brooms and sweep off the frost from the walls and ceilings, then sweep up what had fallen, and light the furnace and keep a low fire on until the building had thawed out. This has now been done, but I have considered it necessary to hire an Indian who lives close to the school, to keep the building fairly warm, by making up the furnace fire in the mornings and nights every day, to prevent the frost accumulating again in the building, which I trust will be approved.

I should be glad to be advised if the desks and other furnishings for this school, which have been requisitioned for have been purchased, and whether any progress has been made regarding the appointment of a teacher.

P.G. Lazenby,

I have your letter of January 28th and the attached letter which you stated was addressed to you by Mr. John W. Thomson in connection with the Fisher River contract with Wylie and Compton.

With reference to fire insurance as we insisted that the contractor insure the buildings during construction I presume that it is in order to allow 10% fee to be claimed by the contractor.

With reference to the cement as this material was Government issue and it was secured at the contractor's request, he being unable to purchase cement, we will not pay the 10% on the expenditure involved in the purchase of the cement. The contractor had no trouble whatever in connection with the acquiring of the cement and we see no reason why he should claim 10% on this item.

With reference to paragraph 4 of Mr. Thomson's letter we are not quite clear as to what he means by board and room of workmen and agency employees paid by the Agency. We presume that he means the meals supplied by the hospital during the time the residence and lighting plant building were constructed for which we have not yet settled the account. What does he mean by Agency employees paid by the Agency. As the contractor was not put to any trouble or expense in connection with furnishing these meals, I see no reason why he should be allowed 10% on any of the expenses other than those for which he was responsible. We saved him a lot of trouble by furnishing the meals and in any event I do not see how he can collect 10% on something for which no definite charge has yet been set. This question has yet to be settled.
We understand from a letter received from Mr. Leesby, dated November 12th, that the contractor provided meals for the men engaged on the construction of the school. On this item, we will, of course, pay the 10%.

I feel quite sure that Nylie and Compton have made more than a fair profit on these buildings.

You will perhaps recall that, following a conversation with me, you wrote to the contractor on September 23, 1947, at which time you indicated our requirements in this regard.

Colonel Henry has already obtained Treasury Board authority to increase from $8,000 to $15,000 the amount required for the construction of the Day School and teacher's residence; corresponding authority is required for the expected increase in the cost of the Clerk's residence.

I have for acknowledgment the Director's letter, of
the 6th instant, File 21-136 S.A.I. in connection with the second
Progress Payment on the new Fisher River Agency Residence, which
arrived during my leave of absence.

With reference to the new Day School, I may say
that this building is completed, and some of the furnishings
for the teacher's quarters have been received, in fact the order
for these furnishings is practically complete. However, no
school desks have come to hand as yet, and until these arrive
we will be unable to commence operating the school. I wrote
the Department regarding the desks on February 3rd last, with
a view of having the delivery made as soon as possible.

Replying to the final paragraph of the Director's
letter, I would say that at first glance the cost of the new
school, and the new residence appears to be rather high. However,
until we have the final detailed statement of the costs of the
various materials used, and the cost of labour, it is difficult
to judge as to whether or not there has been any overcharge on
any of the items. I may say that the basement construction
at both the school and the residence covers a large portion of
the cost, as both these basements are large. As to the labour,
the men employed on these buildings were very good workers, and
did not waste any time. I watched this pretty constantly,
especially in connection with the residence.

I will endeavour to make a fuller report after the
Inspector and Cost Auditor have been here. I may say that
there is still the jacket heater to be installed in the residence,
but I was advised last week, when in Winnipeg, that the plumber
had secured this heater, and would be installing it shortly.

(signed) P.G. Lazenby
Supt Fisher River Agency

Indian Supt., Hodgson, Man.

We wrote to you on April 1 and asked you to see that the jacket heater specified and shown on the drawings was installed, as you had complained that the heater was not of the correct type, and we forwarded to you a copy of our letter to the contractors in this connection.

We have just received from the contractors a letter dated April 17th together with one from the Plumber, Mr. Jones, and I enclose herewith this letter as there is not time to have a copy made. Please see that the proper Jacket heater, as specified and as instructed is installed. Apparently the delay in installation in the first place and the change to a heater that was not specified is due to instructions issued by you that you wished a flat top heater. Attend to this matter immediately by getting in touch with the contractors and the plumber.

In your letter of March 31st you stated that Mr. Thomson, the auditor, was engaged in auditing the accounts but that some of the suppliers' invoices had not been received. We will have to pay the final payment on this work from the 1947-48 funds, as no funds have been provided in the 1948-49 Estimates. Please contact Mr. Thomson and see what is holding up the issuing of the final certificate.

IMPORTANT:

We understand that eight pairs of window shutters complete as specified and shown on the working drawings have not been supplied by the Architect. However, as the building has cost a great deal more than was ever expected, I think we should not at this time consider this additional work and I would ask you to bring to the Auditor's attention the fact that these shutters were not supplied and accounts for them should not be passed.

In commenting on the building (staff residence) Mr. Storeater states: "If exterior stucco was approved as a substitute for asbestos siding shingles, it should be of cement mixture applied on ribbed metal lath".
In this connection please refer to our letter of Sep. 2 in which explicit instructions were given that a first-class stucco job was to be done. Has it been done in accordance with the best practice, namely - as suggested by Mr. Storeater on ribbed metal lath.

In this letter we are writing only about the staff residence, and we are passing on the file to the Superintendent of Education, Col. Henry, in order that he may note and take the necessary action in regard to the matters pertaining to the school and toilets on which Mr. Storeater has reported.

The Chief Engineer recommends that a sum of $250.00 be held back from the amount payable to the Contractor until the work has been satisfactorily completed. A copy of this letter is being given to the Chief Treasury Officer so that the holdback will be retained. I would suggest that you show this letter to the Auditor, Mr. Thomson.

M. W. Director.
Memorandum

Mr. D. B. Gow

Re:- Buildings at Fisher River Indian Reserve, Manitoba.

On March 16 and 17 last, a visit was made to the Peguis Indian Reserve near Hodgson, Manitoba, to inspect the newly constructed Day School, Staff Residence and addition to the Light and Power Plant Building. Mr. P. G. Lazenby, the Indian Agent, was contacted and he provided a set of plans and specifications of the Day School and plans of the Staff Residence.

All the buildings were completed and in the opinion of the writer, the material used is of good quality and the workmanship, with the following one exception, of high order. The basement floor of the Day School was found to be very rough and irregular, also without the finish called for. It should be added that this floor is cracked and slightly heaved in places. In this respect, Mr. Lazenby stated that the building was left unheated for a period after its completion, at which time this occurred. Subsequently, however, the floor has settled back near its original shape.

It would appear very advisable that this floor be repaired at some early date, possibly during the summer school holidays. By preparing a proper bond, it is believed that a finish similar to that specified could be applied to the existing floor.

Following are construction changes noted:

(a) Day School and Teacher's Residence:

1. Interior basement walls plastered,
2. 1/4" Oak Flooring on first and second floor instead of birch or fir,
3. In some instances slab doors provided in place of panelled doors,
4. Exterior of foundation wall above grade plastered and blocked off,
5. Floors of outdoor toilets 1" shiplap instead of 2" planking,
6. Exterior walls of toilets finished with siding similar to that of school, instead of asbestos shingles as indicated on plan.

D. B. Gow, Esq.,
District Chief Engineer,
Department of Mines and Resources,
WINNIPEG, Manitoba.
(b) Staff Residence:

1. Addition in basement of a concrete cistern. Cistern is 5' x 8' x 5½' high; plastered interior and exterior.

2. Exterior finish stucco instead of shingles.

3. Foundation wall above grade plastered and blocked off to a stone effect.

4. Galvanized Iron eavestrough with three down pipes leading to above mentioned cistern.

5. No shutters on house.

6. Concrete walk from front to back of house.

(c) Light and Power Plant Building:

The Light and Power Plant building was enlarged and made to match the existing old building. This addition is 12' x 12' in size and of light frame construction, resting on a concrete slab floor. The interior is sheathed with wallboard directly onto the studding. The exterior walls are sheathed with 1" material and covered with 5/8" drop siding. The roof is covered with cedar shingles laid 4½" to the weather.

(Sgd) O.J. Storsater

O. J. Storsater.
Ottawa, April 27, 1948.

Dear Mr. Davis,

Upon receiving a report from Miss Fairservice, teacher at Murdoch School, Fisher River Reserve, that no water was obtainable from the School well, the undersigned and Mr. Boyne made an investigation with the following results: The well is completely dry.

It appears that when the well was dug there was ample supply of water, this however, must have been surface water. Owing to the extreme drought of last fall the well was pumped dry. Miss Fairservice also complained of the strong alkaline taste in the water when it was available.

Judging from appearances the only solution would be to install a drilled well at the most opportune time, as Miss Fairservice and the school children are drinking water derived from melted snow. As this source of supply will disappear with break-up, early action on this matter is strongly recommended.

Mr. R. Logan
Portage la Prairie, Man.
Dear Sir,

I am sending in my School Returns for June 30; also expenses for gardening & sewing. You will see that the attendance was poor during it. Sorry to say that we don't get along as good with our sewing as the first year, as all the big girls has left school, and there are only four little ones left, two of these are too small to sew at all.

Since January we have made three plain pieces of underwear, a little dress and a boy's shirt. Some of the children were so badly in need of clothes that I let them have these garments. Hoping I was right in doing so.

Our garden this year looks very good so far. We have a large bed of garden peas (on blossom), one bed of beets about six inches high, carrots about three inches high. The set onions looks very nice, have 5 hills of cabbages and 5 of cucumbers (not doing very good). Potatoes are looking very well. Have ten flower beds, but not doing as good as I would like to see them do. Yours respectfully Rose Godon

Dear Mr. Logan;-

Since writing you yesterday Chief Antoine and Councillor Adam Martin were at my place and asked me to write you regarding the small balance of the Land Money. They wish to know if you have heard from Ottawa since you wrote them.

They also asked me to write you and urge you to make a very strong request to the Department to have a day school built near the church at the Lower Reserve as those having children of school age are very anxious to have the children educated and not have to send them away to Kenora or any other Boarding school. I think myself that they should have a school especially when they wish it so badly.

Very truly yours,

I beg to enclose herewith a copy of a letter received from J.C. Ginn, Farm Instructor on the Roseau Reserve in which he refers to a request made by the Indians of the Lower Roseau reserve asking that the Department give them a Day school at this point.

In my report on the schools of Portage la Prairie Agency which was sent to the Department on the 11th of May 1911, I made mention of the request made by the Indians to have a day school on this reserve. The reserve is only four miles from Dominion City and would not be isolated for a teacher. There are eighteen children between the ages of five and fifteen and as most of the parents were themselves educated in Industrial schools they are really anxious to have their children educated but do not like the idea of sending them away to Boarding or Industrial schools. I am also of the opinion that these people would be loyal to a school and that it would serve good purpose at this point.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

Sir,

In reference to your letter of the 5th Instant No. 389267/1 regarding a Day School on the Roseau River Reserve.

In reply I beg to make the following report.

On the 15th Inst., I left Portage and arrived at Dominion City 8 o'clock P.M. On the 16th, drove to the Reserve and had a meeting with the Indians. I placed the matter before them very strongly that if the School was opened it would be temporarily, and if the children attended the School regularly there was hopes of having a School built later on. Chief Antoine stated that he would see himself that the Children attended the School regularly.

The building referred to is the Catholic Church and Chief Antoine stated that Rev. Father Conneau who visits the Reserve at different times, told him that they could have the Church for School purposes. The Church is in good repair, and in my opinion, would answer the purpose nicely, with little or no cost to the Department.

In reference to the qualifications of the Woman who is available as a Teacher, would state that she has no Certificate. I had a talk with her. She is about 30 years of age and taught for some time at Kenora Bdg. School, she was at St Boniface School for ten years. She is married to a treaty named Ed Kipling, of St Peter Reserve, and has been living at Roseau Reserve for some time and wishes to be transferred to Roseau. She talks English well, and I consider she will make good as far as she knows, and the children will all have to start from the beginning. Mr. Ginn, the Farm instructor thinks that she will make a success of it, if the Children attend the School.
On my return from Dominion City, I stopped over in Winnipeg and had a talk with Rev. Father Comeau, and he informed me that Church could be used for the School, and was pleased to know that there was chance of getting a School; he also stated that Mrs Kipling would be alright as a Teacher.

If my report is satisfactory and a School should be granted, kindly advise, and I will forward requisition for School Material.

Your obedient servant,

R. Logan
Indian Agent

REPORT OF INSPECTOR JACKSON ON THE LOWER ROSEAU RIVER DAY SCHOOL.

There were present at inspection one boy and four girls all in Standard O's.

The average for the September quarter was 4.17. There are thirty children within three miles of the school.

Miss Godin informed me that she intended to resign at the end of the present quarter. The attendance in the past has been very poor and the prospects for the future are not bright for this school on account of the difficulty the Roman Catholic Church have in getting good teachers. The present teacher lives at Emerson and goes home every Friday evening returning on Monday morning.

Date of Inspection, October 10th, 1917.
Ottawa, November 24th, 1917.

Sir,

Inspector Jackson who inspected the Lower Roseau River day school on October 10th, reports that the attendance, at this school, in the past, has been very poor.

On the day of his visit there were only 5 children present, although he states that there are thirty children within three miles of the school. As there are such a number of children within a reasonable distance of the school, the Department cannot understand why the attendance is not better.

You will be good enough to point out to these Indians as soon as possible the necessity of them sending their children to school regularly. If they do not do so, you should enforce the regulations.

The Department will expect from you in the near future, a report showing what action you are taking in this matter, and it is hoped that you will be able to report a largely increased attendance.

Extract from Inspector Jackson's report on a visit made to the Roseau River Indian Day School of October 8, 1920.

Original on 127-5-6.

I arrived at this school on the morning of the 8th of October at 9.30 A.M. and found 2 pupils present.

All the pupils she has on the roll and who are attending this quarter are 5.2 boys and 3 girls.

On the register for the September quarter I found the names of 15 pupils, 9 boys and 6 girls, and the average for that quarter was only 2.9.

Miss Goodall, the teacher, was educated at the town of Emerson and went as high as the 6th standard. She has no normal training and has taught for about 4 years.

Miss Goodall was very pessimistic about this school. She says that she has done everything possible on her part to get the children to come to school but without success.

There are about 20 children of school age on this reserve and with a new teacher and a truant officer, it could be made as successful as any of our day schools.

The school is of little or no benefit to the reserve as at present conducted and should be closed at the end of the present quarter.

S. J. Jackson,
Insp.
Ottawa, December 9, 1920.

Sir,

Mr. Inspector Jackson, in a report on his recent inspection of the Roseau River Indian Day School, has drawn the attention of the Department to the very poor attendance. He states that on the register for the September quarter he found an enrolment of fifteen pupils, while the average for that quarter was only 2.9. He states that there are about twenty children of school age on this reserve and recommends that, if a better attendance is not secured, the school be closed at the end of the present quarter.

Unless the Indian parents take advantage of the educational facilities provided the Department would not be warranted in continuing the expense involved by keeping this school open. You should inform the Indians that it is expected that they will see that their children attend regularly, as, if a better attendance is not secured, this school will have to be closed. I shall be pleased to have a report from you regarding the matter.

Your obedient servant,

Proposed Roseau River Indian Day School.

I have had a long discussion with Major Clark concerning the establishment of this school, and he has recommended the following:

(a) That we advertise for tenders for the construction of plan 886;

(b) That this school be sited just south of the house of Sam Hayden, which is on the left bank of the river about three quarters of a mile north on the trail leading from the farm instructor's house to the Chief's house;

(c) That a well cannot be dug, due to the presence of salt water. This will mean an ice house will have to be provided and the school will have to be fairly close to the river to make the carrying of water convenient.

(d) That due to the possibility of spring floods, the foundations should be at least a foot higher than usual.

It would seem, therefore, that we can now proceed with the advertising of tenders for the construction of this school, based on plan 886 but with the foundation to be at least one foot higher than that provided normally in the blueprints and specifications.

THE GOVERNOR GENERAL IN COUNCIL,

The undersigned has the honour to report:

THAT the Indian Affairs Branch of the Department of Mines and Resources has provided for the construction of a one-room Indian Day School and attached teacher's residence on the Roseau River Indian Reserve, Portage la Prairie Indian Agency, Province of Manitoba, for the education of the Indian children living there;

THAT, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Act, tenders have been advertised for in local and trade newspapers;

THAT we have received, as a result of these advertisements, the following five tenders:

North American Lumber & Supply Co.,
720 Royal Bank Bldg., Winnipeg, Man., .... $11,200.

S.A. Gariepy, St. Jean Baptiste, Man., ..... No firm tender

Richard Desilets, Elie, Man., ............... $19,840.

North American Buildings Ltd.,
720 Royal Bank Bldg., Winnipeg, Man., .... $11,543.89

Maple Leaf Construction Co.,
777 Erin St., Winnipeg, Man., ............. $13,500.

THAT the above tenders have been examined by Departmental officials and it is found that they comply with the conditions outlined on tender forms which had been prepared by the Indian Affairs Branch and the plans and specifications as prepared by the Lands and Development Services Branch;

THAT Departmental officials recommend the acceptance of the lowest tender, namely that of the North American Lumber and Supply Company, Winnipeg, Manitoba, in an amount of Eleven Thousand, Two Hundred Dollars ($11,200.00);

THAT funds are available for this purpose in Vote 230, 1949-50, Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources.

The undersigned, therefore, recommends the acceptance of the tender of North American Lumber and Supply Company, of Winnipeg, Manitoba, for the erection of this one-room school and teacher's residence, for the amount of Eleven Thousand Two Hundred Dollars ($11,200.00).

Respectfully submitted,

BFH/IM
Minister of Mines and Resources.

September 19, 1949.

Mr. R. S. Davis,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,
538 Dominion Public Building,
Winnipeg, Manitoba.

Roseau River Indian Day School.

Five tenders were received in answer to our advertisements for the erection of this school. The lowest was from the North American Lumber and Supply Company, Limited, 720 Royal Bank Building, Winnipeg, Manitoba, in the amount of $11,200.00. Its acceptance was recommended and we have now received authority by P.C. 4608 to let the contract for the erection of the school to this company.

Please find attached the contract for signature by the signing officials of this company. Please note the tender is not from North American Buildings, Limited, as their tender was higher than that from North American Lumber and Supply Company.

You will find attached a supply of Progress Payment forms which are to be submitted by Mr. Hamilton, in accordance with Article 3 (b) of the contract. I am sending this letter to you in duplicate so that a copy can be sent to Mr. Hamilton.

It will be necessary for Mr. Hamilton to requisition for janitor supplies, furniture for the teacher's residence, school desks and a space heater for the classroom on or about the middle of October. This will ensure that the school is ready to begin operation immediately after the Christmas holidays.

Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.
